title: Wistanstow and Flounders' Folly Walk Route

images.title: Flounders' Folly from the north-east by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Flounders' Folly from the north-east. Benjamin Flounders was a prominent English Quaker with business interests in key new industries and developments at the time of the Mid-Industrial Revolution, such as The Stockton and Darlington Railway (of which he was a founding Director) and new canals in his native North-East England.

images.title: Looking northeast from Flounders' Folly by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking northeast from Flounders' Folly. From the tower their are fine views of the Stretton Hills, Wenlock Edge, the Long Mynd and Clee Hills and even further afield to the Brecon Beacons, Radnor Hills, Malvern Hills and Black Mountains.

images.title: Flounders Folly walk this way - Lower Dinchope, Shropshire by Martin Richard Phelan, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Flounders Folly walk this way

images.title: Plough and brewery 2 - Wistanstow, Shropshire by Martin Richard Phelan, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Plough and brewery in Wistanstow

images.title: The Quinny Brook south of Strefford village by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Quinny Brook south of Strefford village

images.title: Field below Flounders Folly by David Smith, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Field below Flounders Folly

description: The Shropshire based village of Wistanstow lies just to the north of Craven Arms in the beautiful Shropshire Hills. This walk from the village visits a well loved local historical site. You can reach Flounders' Folly by following footpaths east from Wistanstow, passing the Quinny Brook and Strefford Wood on the way. This will take you to Callow Hill where you can climb to the Grade II listed folly which was built in 1838 by Benjamin Flounders. On certain days you can even climb the tower and enjoy wonderful views to the Malvern Hills, the Black Mountains of Wales and Cader Idris. To continue your walking in the area you can enjoy some more fine views at the nearby Wenlock Edge or explore the valley of the River Corve on the Corvedale Three Castles Walk to the east. Please scroll down for the full list of walks near and around Wistanstow. The detailed maps below also show a range of footpaths, bridleways and cycle paths in the area.
